Reviews.Title: Mega Kudos to Canon for their PowerShot A1300
Reviews.Author: Stan
Reviews.Content: As a full time professional photographer for 15 yrs. now retired, I was dissapointed  not to find a quality pocket  camera  with anoptical viewfinder, until now. I consider this a critical part of any camera that is not an SLR. LCD screens should not be the onlyfinder on a camera. I have been using the A1300 for a few weeks now. It has performed perfectly in a great variety  of situationsand lighting  conditions in both auto & program  modes. The viewfinder  tracks with the optical 5X tele. very well. Am very serprisedat how good the 20X digital zoom & stabilization  are.The LCD is bright and adjustable. In the real world of point & shoot photography, not lab tests, this ultra compact took really good photos! Very happy it  uses AA cells. I use Ni.Mh rechargeables &always have extra Alkalines along.. Batt. life has been good. This is the easiest, most fun and now my go to camera. The A1300 is aVery well thought out and executed point & shoot camera.  Thanks Canon for making something we really need at a veryaffordable price!

Reviews.Title: Great backpacking camera.
Reviews.Author: hiker
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera as a replacement for my Nikon Coolpix that quit working after less than two years and probably less than five-hundred pictures.  I use this camera when I am backpacking as it is very lightweight and uses standard AA batteries.  My first experience was this month on a fifty mile hike of the Foothill Trail in South Carolina.  There are many waterfalls and beautiful views and I wanted to take some great pictures.  I was extremely happy with the results.  I returned home with about sixty photos and loaded them to Picassa with the idea of editing and correcting any problems before sharing them with friends and family.  None of the sixty needed any retouching.  They were perfect both in exposure and color rendetion.  Some of the pictures were taken at night of my campfire with the camera set on the A (automatic) position.  They were great.As usual, buying through Amazon was a perfect transaction.

Reviews.Title: Once again, a Canon, with (of course) an optical viewfinder
Reviews.Author: D. Chambers
Reviews.Content: For background: we've had a Canon A20, with a magnificent 2 Megapixels (grin), for the last 10 years. One was stolen in airport baggage (my stupidity for packing it). I was thankfully able to buy a replacement A20 on e-Bay. So we have been quite content for about 10 years. This A20 has been bulletproof, you might say.  Fast Forward to 2012. My spouse wanted a smaller, lighter camera--No problem......But I wanted an optical viewfinder--BIG problem; hardly anyone makes them any more. Thank you Canon, for still providing this feature.For those of you wondering what is this -- an optical viewfinder? It is simply a camera that you place up against your cheek, and perhaps use the zoom buttons, to compose the picture. This is how you used to do it with film cameras, before LCD screens were even invented. Single-Lens-Reflex (SLR) cameras, that cost vastly more, use this method, although with vastly improved optics. The alternative is to hold your (non-viewfinder) camera out at arm's length. Which results in:-- Get out your glasses, cuz you can't see enough detail on the toy screen.-- Then, when you finally see your pix, you realize that your cam is unsupported--this will cause BLUR. So you have to take another...-- Then, you hit your forehead with your fist (in anguish) as you realize that the sun is shining so strongly that you cannot see anything on the little screen at all.Then, you retire to the bar and regret not buying a camera with an optical viewfinder. Get 'em while they last. For the price of a bottle of Champagne, you could have bought this camera. Attention: you can still use the LCD screen at arm's length on this camera if you wanna.The other reviews are great; I wanted to call out great emphasis on the viewfinder. Sports and wildlife photographers rely on such viewfinders, since they can track, zoom, and compose a shot (in a fraction of a second) which would be impossible with an LCD display.For those of you thinking of using a cellphone or an i-Pad for photography, fuhgettaboudit. Their pix are horribly granulated (few pixels & small sensors), and as with any handheld, the blurring is atrocious. I know; I've tried. Try not to shame yourself by sharing such pictures.This camera is magnificent. Over the  years I have done darkroom film development, printed enlargements from the negatives, carried camera bags full of changeable lenses for my SLR, had slide projectors; now this is all I need. I can't imagine spending money on a more expensive camera, unless you want to move up to a nice SLR, but that will be bulky and heavy. This cam is 6oz, versus 12.5 for my beloved old A20.I find that most of my relatives and friends take lots of pictures (be it on a cellphone or camera) and then never DO ANYTHING with them. They are not shared with anyone, and mostly just sit on chips or CDs in drawers. So it is worthwhile to point out that this camera includes Canon's album software; the chip pops out for easy unloading (or use the cable connector)--to help us get organized.If you would like a case for this, consider the "Lowepro - Tahoe 10 Digital Camera Bag - (various colors)" which is a softcase. I've done trial fits at Beste Buye and it works fine. I ended up buying the Kodak "Essentials" hard case. The Case Logic units that I tried were a tad too small.A final word on chargers and batteries. There is no charger. This cam uses two AA batteries; if you need them they are globally available from Topeka to Taipei to Tuscany. If you buy a charger camera, consider: You have one more charger to carry. You already have phone chargers, GPS chargers, Blackberry/i-Pad/PC chargers. Some have two different cables: one 12-volt for a car, and one 120-volt for the wall. Does your cam charger work on dual-voltage 120/220? If not you will need to buy a second one (220v) at great expense for overseas travel. Not to mention another prong-converter for when you finally travel overseas. Ugh. [But do see notes on rechargeables in the Comments On This Review, below]Shopping notes:  This camera does NOT come with a memory card (but does have batteries). Amazon has a good 4GB SD card for about $6. Add it to your shopping cart. When checking out, do NOT buy either of these things with 1-Click, or you will lose free shipping. Add them to the cart, then go to checkout, then change the shipping method to "free shipping", then complete.Please comment if you have issues and I will try to address them. Cheers y'all.xxx ooo xxxPS. For me the image size is important for some of my software (it probably won't matter to most people) so just be aware: The A1300 can be set to take 640x480, 1600x1200, or any of 3 even larger formats. My old A20 could take 1024x768 format, but that is not available on the A1300.

Reviews.Title: Canon A1300
Reviews.Author: Ken Blkaney
Reviews.Content: Canon A1300 Sure ShotPros - Has an optical viewfinder !! - a must have in bright sunlight  Uses two AA batteries !! - can buy at almost any store  Confortable in your hand and fits nicely in shirt pocket or purse  Takes a very good still photo  Takes a very good HD Video with good single audio (non-stereo)  Can also take a fairly good standard video  with single audio - good for saving SD Card space  Audio sounds fairly good when having to video in gusty wind conditions - as compared to some other brand cameras  Very easy to use and easy to switch back and forth from Auto to Low Light, etc  and easy to switch back and forth from flash and no flash  Video button on back is separate from the still shot button on top- I like that because I take mostly videos  Very good camera for the priceCons - The videos and still photos are occasionally very blurry and non-usable - as though the auto focus has failed  ( I just turn the camera off and start over again (reboot) and then it is fine )  The optical viewfinder does not show the zoom in/out when videoing but the the LCD does show the zoom in/out while videoing  Does not come with an SD Card - Camera does not have any internal memory so you must buy an SD card  Standard AA batteries last only about one hour when videoing - I recommend using the rechargeable batteries to save moneyConclusion - I like this camera and I would give this camera at least a four star if it were not for the above listed cons - This camera is an  inexpensive point and shoot pocket camera and I recommend this camera.

Reviews.Title: Canon A1300
Reviews.Author: Bruce W. hathcock
Reviews.Content: Smal portable camera east to operate even without reading a manual if you are used to digital camera, excellet picture quality, even when in moving car the stabilty is supurb. Zoom is good except the last 6x zoom which is digital once it hits the limit of the optical zoom the digital is almost worthless. However for fast snap shots on the fly it's a nice working camera and the price is about right. This was used to replace a Pentax digital camera. The pentax would not accept the 64 gig flash disk but the A1300 does. Easy to handle comfortable to hold and like that it's not just another sqware box. Night flash works good and face detecton is nice too. would buy another one.After haveing this camera for a short time have found that the memory card and battery has issues. Buyer beware of this issue you will try to take a picture and it dies out have tried new batteris and everything sending it to factoy for repair

Reviews.Title: Very good for the price, but supplied software has issues
Reviews.Author: b in MA "~B"
Reviews.Content: I bought this to replace an old Cannon which took a dive in a lake and didn't survive.  This camera is actually cheaper than the one it replaced, though it has more features.  Build quality is quite good. I really like having a viewfinder and using AA rechargeable batteries.  If you have ever been stuck with a camera that uses proprietary batteries you will understand.  One can always by AA batteries to keep going. Also, I seldom use a much larger camera I have since I find it easier to take along a camera that will fit into a pocket. The 5x  Zoom works well, and the pictures come out quite good. I don't like using digital zoom which reduces the pixels used.  I was especially pleased with the macro setting... pictures of flowers are quite stunning.The camera has lots of features, but many are buried in the menus.  You really need to read the manual (which is a pdf file on the disc) in order to get the most out of it. ISO and shutter speed settings are all there, once you discover them.I am an amateur photographer, so I do have a lot of pictures in the My Pictures folder (Using Windows).  To my surprise, the Image Express software supplied with the camera told me that I had way too many pictures for it to work. After that message it promptly closes the program.  Tried it several times, and I suppose there are work-arounds on this issue.  Fortunately, it is redundant software.since Windows immediately recognizes the camera and flawlessly transfers the pictures from the camera to the hard drive. My recommendation is to skip that program during the customized install (the other software seems to work, though I usually use the consumer version of Photoshop.No, this isn't a massive high end camera and doesn't pretend to be.  But, overall, this is a lot of camera for the money. Small enough to carry around and flexible enough to adjust for lighting and circumstances.

Reviews.Title: Great Little Camera
Reviews.Author: Gary J. Huffstidler "Bluesman"
Reviews.Content: I bought this small camera to replace a Kodak camera I got fed up with, because on a sunny day outside you could notsee the image screen. This Cannon is one of the very few small digital cameras that still has an optical view finder.The view finder zooms when the camera zooms and it cured my problem. Pictures are very good. Fairly easy to use. I would reccomend it.

Reviews.Title: Great little camera!
Reviews.Author: Patricia T.
Reviews.Content: I love this camera! Perfect for my mountain biking and bird watching trips when I don't want to carry my expensive camera equipment around for fear of damaging it. Don't let the size fool you, it takes great quality photos & video! Fits in my pocket so I never miss  a good photo opportunity. I've even gotten some excellent  bird and wildlife pictures made clear & sharp by the stabilized zoom! I was really pleasantly surprised at the quality of this camera. Canon cameras are the best!

Reviews.Title: A1300 - Good Value
Reviews.Author: B. Holst
Reviews.Content: I shopped extensively before buying the A1300 Canon. I weighed the value of using a pair of AA cells versus a dedicated power pack. I included the ability to use rechargeable cells - the precharged cells with long shelf life. Because this is a grab-and-go camera, it needs to be ready at a moment's notice. AA cells are great for that. And it's the camera our 10 year old will use and he's not at all good about keeping his electronic gizmoz charged, so the AA feature is a plus there. I also like the optical view finder. Holding a camera at arm's length is the norm, but heads are fairly steady, so the camera is also quite steady when used with the optical finder. It's a simple tunnel, but it is accurate and simple. I also kept in mind the fact that this is a camera in the $100 price range and there is no reason to expect lens quality, flash range, manual control or any other feature to be equal to a camera in the $200 or higher price range. So we shopped and ordered from Amazon.Delivery was on time as expected. The camera came with all of the accessories listed in the ad - a very basic kit. Our first go with this piece was disappointing. It seems that even the major manufacturers can produce a dud from time to time. Our A1300 was a battery hog. I immediately contacted Canon through their website, explained the problem and what I had done to try to correct the problem. They asked that I return the camera to them and the replacement arrived in less than one week. The new one is spot-on.So what about the A1300? The AUTO function is impressive. It does more than I ever expected a point and shoot to do - automatically. The color brightness and focus are good and the photo details are great. I don't see any odd colors and it does adjust to ensure people are people colored, no matter what the color of the people. So if the photos from the A1300 are good, How good is good? My Canon S3 takes a VERY GOOD photo. My friends Canon EOS DSLR takes EXCELLENT photos. It's not an issue of photo size, it's quality and clarity. And this little camera holds it's ground very well. I also have a lesser brand camera about the same size as the A1300 that takes poor quality photos. Sure I can tell what the photo is, who is in it and where we were, and the features of that one are excellent but it's just not crisp in the details. So in my opinion, a good photo is one that doesn't give me any particular reason to complain. I'm sure there are aberations that a pro could find in a detailed review, but that's not why I got this camera. This one is in the glove box, in the pocket of my motorcycle jacket and at family functions where I don't want the obvious BIG camera that makes people nervous. It takes a far better photo than my cell phone.At full optical zoom at about 150 feet I can count the blades of grass in my neighbor's lawn with the camera set at 16mp.  I am not used to having such a wide angle on a digital camera and I am getting scenery shots that look great. It handles the light whether I am shooting into the sun or with the sun at my back. I have not tried some of the special programs offered, but of the ones that I have tried, the low light setting allows me to get very nice photos in museum lighting. The Stealth option is both low light and silent so the camera is not a bother when discretion is needed. And the digital IS mode works well. I'm past my prime and I'm not as steady as I once was. Our boy is young and is also not rock steady. Digital IS gives us a good shot every time. The video function gives me bright and clear HD videos - or far more compact 640x480 videos. I wish the zoom worked with in video mode but that's one thing I gave up in this price range. For motorcycle trips with the guys, it's great to be able to set the camera to 640x 480 and just shoot lots of pics that are easy to email and look fine on the computer monitor. Shooting one handed as I ride doesn't always get me a great shot, but if I shoot enough shots I get plenty of great photos to share. Fun - cheap - reliable - great quality. What else could I ask from a $100 price range camera?  But, you don't want to drop it into the lake. That's another story and there are far better models if that's part of your plan.

Reviews.Title: A1300 has it all
Reviews.Author: Mary J. Norman
Reviews.Content: I LOVE THIS CAMERA A1300 WHICH USES 2 AA BATTERIES!!!loaded with many highly desireable features, has a viewfinder as well which I use only occasionally for special purposes. I did a lot of research covering many many hours to find the best camera with as many features as possible and Canon proved to have it all!My last camera was a Kodak which finally gave out after like 12 years and was 5MP.  The A1300 camera is full of upgraded features like 16MP without a big price and has the AA batteries which is my first requirement!  Since Kodak is going out of the Camera business, I did try to get one anyway, but the lousy quality was shocking as the button to take a photo was RECESSED and a real PAIN to try to work with it.  I could not tolerate this and returned it as I need a good camera loaded with features to take excellent photos as possible for my buyers of puppies.  Pups are usually quick movers and is tough to get a good photo.  You can take 30 photos and only end up with a couple of good ones, so fighting a camera in addition is not worth it and very stressful. This is one excellent reasonably priced all around state of the art camera being a point and shoot camera!  YOU MUST USE A MEMORY CARD TO TAKE ANY PHOTOS. Anyway, I love it!

Reviews.Title: Canon Power Shot A1300 IS 16.0
Reviews.Author: JCNH
Reviews.Content: Great camera for the price. Purchased the camera in May 2012 to shoot family events, friends ect. You could not ask for a better price vs performance camera. Very simple to use, excellent picture and video quality. I would suggest getting a cushioned camera case that includes the USB thumb drive reader for $10, the case is perfect for travel and storage when not in use. The USB reader is a great option when offloading the memory card.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Gordon
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera because I needed a smaller digital camera with a viewfinder, I use it for work and am outside in West Texas where the sun makes a camera screen unusable. This camera has made my job a lot easier keeping me from having to go back to take more photo's.

Reviews.Title: Great little camera!!
Reviews.Author: Blaine C. Palmer
Reviews.Content: The new Canon Powershot A1300 contains a feature no other currently available major low cost compact digital camera has which I consider absolutely essential for my type of photography -- a viewfinder.  Probably 80% of my pictures are taken in sunlight.  In the sun of mid day, the viewing screen is practically usless in composing your photo shot.  Kudos to Canon for recognizing this need and making a compact camera with a viewfinder.  The image stabilizer is an incredible feature for a $110 camera.  The camera is very simple to operate, and is a 16 mp, so the outdoor scenes as well as closeups and indoor shots are amazingly clear!  This camera takes better photos than some SLR's I have owned.  Thanks for making us bargain hunters happy!!!  Blaine Palmer

Reviews.Title: BEST LITTLEST DIGITAL CAMERA
Reviews.Author: wojciech galazka
Reviews.Content: i bought this camera because i have an canon eos rebel and many time the size of rebel complicate to move freele . in the comparison between this two, i can said that this canon a1300 taking photos during daylight has the same performance like the eos rebel but in little body presentation. however at night you can program the exposure to 800 or 1600 iso and you can increase the exposute +1/3 or more to increase the light on pictures. i recomend this camera because has the best relation between size/price/picture cuality.

Reviews.Title: Excellent camera!
Reviews.Author: J. Hannan "Just-a-dream"
Reviews.Content: The Canon Powershot A1300IS, purchased from Amazon, exceeded our expectations, and was given quite a thorough workout during a recent vacation, both outside and indoors.Among its most important features is the optical "peep sight," which is invaluable under bright sunlight conditions, which can cause glare on the view-screen. Also appreciated is the rapid "warm-up" time and the range of capabilities from close-up-to-wide-angle-to-telephoto.A pleasant surprise is the long life of the pencell batteries, which, based upon previous camera experience, were expected to require frequent replacement. Not so! On that subject, however, we find that caution is needed while installing and replacing the memory card, because the adjacent batteries tend to fall out,depending upon the angle the camera is held. But one quickly learns to allow for that, as well as in carefully closing the sliding cover door.Although we own various other good cameras, this one has become a favorite!The Hannans, Joan & Bill

Reviews.Title: poor quality pictures
Reviews.Author: Irish Girl
Reviews.Content: I was looking for a smaller camera that I could throw in my purse and use to take pictures at events. I was excited to see this camera had a optical viewfinder, since I hate using the LCD screen. For me, the big test in the quality of a camera is seeing how it takes pictures of people. This newer camera with more megapixels took noticeably poorer pictures then my old Sony Cybershot. T took the same pic of the same person from the same angel with both cameras to compare. No doubt the newer camera was a step down. Both are point and shoot. The only reason I brought the Canon was because I wanted a smaller camera. I guess I will keep looking! I am returning it tomorrow!

Reviews.Title: Good buy
Reviews.Author: John C. Turner
Reviews.Content: I like the camera quite a bit. You can force flash, which was a feature missing on earlier models. The movie mode is not so great - it's rather jerky, but DOES have a microphone.

Reviews.Title: katieb
Reviews.Author: kb in florida
Reviews.Content: This is just what I was looking for...a wide angle lens. The digital image stabilized zoom has an excellent auto focus.

Reviews.Title: Great Product! Canon does it again!
Reviews.Author: Wilma L. Ellsworth "SoundGeekFreak"
Reviews.Content: My daughter got this camera first because it was recommended by a professional photographer as a great entry level digital camera with a lot of manual functions. After using her camera a few times I had to get my own. The features and image quality are what sold me on this sweet little camera. It is 16 MP with HD video and the video is surprisingly good and the audio is not bad either.I took it on a kayaking trip to some very scenic places this summer and it really delivered. Its size makes it easy to take along and it fit nicely in my waterproof box. It fires up quick and lets you get those shots before the moment passes you by. I found it very intuitive and easy to learn its features after a few days of use. I even use the software to retrieve and edit my photos. It comes with "image browser" that is a preview and basic photo editing program that is mac and pc compatible. I love this little camera and it makes taking pictures fun. It has some built in effects that are nice and useful like color enhancement, Black and white, fish-eye lens, etc.It has a viewfinder wich is also nice because you can turn off the screen and extend battery life. In bright sunlight you can't see the screen anyway, so having a viewfinder is helpful. It doesn't eat batteries like other cameras that I have owned. If you want to see some pictures taken with this camera here is a link to my blog. It has some landscape photos and some photos using the zoom to get close shots of some wildlife.[...]I highly recommend this camera to anyone looking for an affordable camera that delivers professional results without having to take a photography class. This might be the best camera for the money out there.

Reviews.Title: Pocketsize, but not so sharp
Reviews.Author: Howard Greybeard
Reviews.Content: Pros include price and size.  Under a hundred bucks seems to be a pretty good price.  The size is truly convenient.  This one fits easily into a shirt pocket. While it includes a potentially useful viewfinder which is unfortunately not parallax corrected so what you see is not quite what you get.  The saddest feature is a 16 mp sensor, which implies pretty good resolution, but since the lens is not very sharp that level of resolution is meaningless.  With that lack of sharpness shots from a trip to England's Lake District were disappointing making this camera less of a bargain than one might initially think.  While I wasn't expecting the detail of an 8x10 view camera, I was hoping for something better than the digital equivalent of an instamatic.

Reviews.Title: a lot of power in an inexpensive package!
Reviews.Author: Thomas E. Curley
Reviews.Content: I bought the Canon Powershot A1300 to replace a Canon Powershot SD850 IS that had developed a focusing problem. On the plus side; it has double the resolution at 16 megapixels, a little more zoom (5x), and HD recording. The A1300 is slightly taller, but is lighter than the SD850. The wider lens angle is a bonus on the A1300 also. Sunlight pictures are fast and sharp on both, but the A1300 had a noticeable recycle delay compared to the SD850. I'm assuming that is due to the AA batteries, although I was using Nihm rechargeables. The SD850 came with a rechargeable Nihm battery, and in my experience, they seem to work better. The A1300 used the flash in many situations were it was not needed. It's easy to turn off, but you need to remember to turn it back on. Both cameras took good low light pictures. Canon resolved one issue with previous Powershots, including the SD850, they made the battery compartment door more secure. Older models had a habit of sliding open during use, shuting down the camera. The A1300 can still be slid open, but has a small clip to make it less likely by accident. One thing I miss from the SD850 is the mode selector dial. Now it's on screen, which could be a problem in bright daylight. The power switch is moved to the top and easier to push on the A1300. The SD850 feels more expensive (and it was) than the A1300. It's heavier, and looks more solid. The A1300 looks plastic (it is)and is noticeably lighter, which may be a plus. At less than $100 though, the A1300 packs a lot of value in that samll package. It fits in a pocket or purse, can substitute AA alkalines in a pinch, takes great pictures and has both a viewfinder and a LCD screen. I haven't taken any video yet. I only use pocket cameras for video if a video camera isn't available. I'll comment later on that.The A1300 falls in the compact camera range. They should be easy to use, light, easy to carry, and have features that allow good sharp pictures in most situations. The A1300 fills that slot at a minimum cost. Now that cameras are electronic and digital, they upgrade as often as PCs. The A1300 is inexpensive, yet gives results that rival expensive SLR cameras. At this price, you can buy one now and donate it in 3 years to buy an upgraded model, or give it to your kid.April 1, 2013 - Update: I've used the camera under several lighting conditions. In outdoor light, it takes excellent pictures, however indoor existing light leaves much to be desired. It is grainy, and focus is not very good, with very short focus range. I also noticed multicolored lines (vertical) when shooting indoor. Not sure why. Severe lag time using flash due to long recharge times. I've since upgraded to a Canon SX40HS, a far superior camera. The A1300 ruined many existing light and flash photos. The SX40HS took fantastic shots under any condition. It costs alot more, but worth it when the shot is priceless!

Reviews.Title: Canon PowerShot A1300: careful!
Reviews.Author: Kevin P.
Reviews.Content: This is my second Powershot.  I like it because it has a viewfinder and takes AA batteries.  However, this camera - at least the one that I bought - is very challenged to take good pictures when lighting conditions are not optimal. I would not use this camera for anything serious indoors, like a wedding.  Maybe I am spoiled by my previous Powershot and other cameras (Nikon, Panasonic).  One positive: the different trick modes are pretty cool and fun to play with. Caution if you mainly want to take pictures inside.

Reviews.Title: Great Lower Price Camera
Reviews.Author: selkirksam
Reviews.Content: This is my second Canon PowerShot camera.  My previous camera, a Canon Powershot 450, was going strong after five years, but it was stolen.  I wanted to more or less duplicate that camera.  The A1300 was a close match, but it had more expanded features and was about one third the cost of the original Powershot.  Pictures are great and the video feature is very clear and easy to use.

Reviews.Title: Soft, Soft, Soft
Reviews.Author: John D. Simkins, Jr. "NJDUCKS"
Reviews.Content: I preordered this camera and have hundreds of shots taken under every imaginable condition after receiving it.I have to say that even after exploring every conceivable setting, both auto and manual, this camera absolutely defiesits MP rating and even its brand heritage.  Canon P&S;'s simply do not produce images this ( Sorry Canon) SOFT. My half decade old A550 (That I dont even use any more) absolutely annihilates this camera.... Shot for shot...condition for condition. Completely  stunned as a lifetime "Canon guy" .  -John

Reviews.Title: Canon Powershot A1300 Camera
Reviews.Author: Melanie Norman
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera as an upgrade of my Panasonic and am very pleased with the quality, simplicity and price!

Reviews.Title: Best camera for the money I have used
Reviews.Author: J. Bruha
Reviews.Content: While not a professional photographer by any means, I have used all sorts of cameras, from the disposables, to SLRs, both digital and 35MM.  Except for the near pro-grad 35MM camera that I got at a yard sale for next to nothing, this Canon is probably the most camera I have gotten for the money.Image quality is very, very good, with a couple caveats.  First is the potential for blur.  Any time you are in a low-light situation, the shutter seems to be open longer than it would be on an SLR, so it is not so good on low light action shots, and be sure in low light situations to hold the camera very still, as any shakes will result in blur, as well.  It is probably not any worse than any other compact point and shoot, but definately noticable coming from an SLR.  The other comment is the delay, both the split second delay from the time you hit the button until the picture is taken (which is greatly reduced by pressing the shutter button halfway down, which focuses the camera, and preps it for the shot) and the time it takes for the flash to recharge.  Using photo batteries helps the flash recharge faster, but it still isn't up to par with my SLR or my wifes full-size Canon.The zoom works well, and leaves the pictures clear, all the way to the limits of the optical zoom.  Like any other digital camera that adds a digital zoom on top of the optical zoom, picture quality starts to drop, as the digital zoom increases.Now, to the reasons why I bought it, and why I recommend it.The pictures are of quite good quality, very clear up to 8X10, and even beyond in good light, even surprisingly good, considering the camera's size and price point.  It also takes very good pics with the flash, or in low light on still objects.The main reasons I bought this particular camera, however, have to do with practicality.  It is small, about the size of a deck of cards, but just a little thicker.  However, for it's small size, it has a fairly large screen in the back, as well as a standard viewfinder (if you are outside, with the sun behind you, a viewfinder works much better than the screen).Also, it takes standard sized AA batteries, of all types.  I have tried it with standard batteries, alkaline batteries, photo batteries, and Li-Ion rechargable batteries.  The camera worked flawlessly, with all of them, really the only differences between them are how many pics you can take on a set of batteries, and how fast the flash recharges.  Normally, I have a pair of rechargables in the camera, and another pair in the case, and have gotten by fine with that so far.  Once a few years ago, we took a family vacation, and our camera batteries went dead, and we could do nothing until we charged them up overnight.  With this camera, I could have bought batteries at about any convenience store, and been fine.It also uses a standard removable SD card, which I like.  Again, on vacation, I can use one card for each day, and have the pictures half sorted right away.I guess the strongest reason I can give for recommending this camera is that it is now the most used one in the household.  It is small enough to take with you anywhere, it is simple and easy to use (very straightforward controls, laid out in a common sense way), it boots up very quickly, meaning it takes very little time from when you turn it on, to when you can take pictures, and lastly, it has good photo quality.  Anymore, we don't even break out my wife's 'good' camera anymore, except to take family portriats, or other things we might want bigger than 8X10.

Reviews.Title: Canon PowerShot A1300
Reviews.Author: SageTrek
Reviews.Content: This point-and-shoot camera takes good photos, is easy to use, and is light weight.I have used versions of the Canon PowerShot for years. I shoot mostly outdoor photographs. Two of the reasons I choose PowerShot cameras for trips and outdoor photos is 1) they have an optical view finder, and 2) they use AA batteries.Without an optical viewfinder, in bright sunlight it can be difficult to see the scene to be photographed or the last photo taken when looking at the LCD screen. Optical view finders are getting harder to find on point-and-shoot cameras. Powershot photos always shows a little more of the scene than the scene viewed through the view finder. And, the view finder seems to aim a little high.Use of AA batteries is important to me when traveling because, in most countries, AA batteries are readily available. I generally use rechargeable AA batteries; but off-the-shelf AA batteries work when needed.The 5x zoom capability is nice, but it takes a couple of seconds after using the zoom dial before the camera actually adjusts the lens. It's not instantaneous.

Reviews.Title: Poor quality photos indoors
Reviews.Author: Robin Brownfield
Reviews.Content: No matter how I set this camera, the quality of the photos taken indoors is quite murky. There is also a painfully long wait between photos.  A camera that takes so long to process and reload for the next photo is not good for taking photos of anything that moves, so subjects as simple as pets or small children - out.  Great for taking photos of parts of buildings outdoors.  Great for taking photos of fully cooperative adults close up.  OK for taking photos of flowers.  Sucks for anything else.

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: This is a great camera. I thought it would be a problem, because there is no sport setting, but the auto setting has the moving objects in focus every time.  Will recommend to anyone.

Reviews.Title: Good camera
Reviews.Author: Starfish1
Reviews.Content: I wanted a "cheap" camera that took decent pictures. My first camera got crushed, my second fell off the roof of my car.I had gotten this one on sale for $89.99. It is very sturdy feeling, and takes good out door pictures. It takes decent indoor pictures, but I have found that "cheap" digital cameras always do. The battery door is a bit flimsy, but will be OK unless you mistreat it. The USB port cover just pops off, doesn't stick in like some do. I have taken about 20-50 pictures with most of the settings, and they turned out well, except the ones I screwed up. If you have the camera on AUTO, it will make all of the decisionss for you, and will not be overridden. BUT you can turn on the P(program) setting, and its OK. The only things I mark on are the battery door, and the auto. But I don't think those detract from the camera.

Reviews.Title: Great little camera
Reviews.Author: DLH
Reviews.Content: Picked up this camera to use for summer events coming up.... First time out- worked really well, and without having to read a 10 page manual to figure out basic functions. Super clear pictures without a big fuss! I like simple.

Reviews.Title: DO NOT BUY THIS CAMERA!
Reviews.Author: Keith
Reviews.Content: The functions and features of this camera are very good for the price... that is... IF YOU CAN GET THE FREAKIN' THING TO WORK!!!Shortly after purchasing the camera my screen went black and I could not see any images in the LCD view finder.  (Menu works fine.  You don't lose the display until you enter view-finder mode)  Apparently the camera still works, but you get only a black image finder.in the view finder when trying to take a picI went to the Internet looking for fixes.  I found scores of complaints about the same issue  (Cannon must be aware of this issue, yet they are still selling this camera.  Makes me less than enthusiastic about ever buying another Cannon product)  One fix was to change the batteries (didn't work)  Another fix was to reset the camera (didn't work)Then there was a pretty ridiculous fix: strike the camera on the palm of your hand with the power on.  THAT FIXED IT!!!Ridiculous.Cannon should issue a recall for this camera.  Until they do I have lost a considerable amount of respect for them as a consumer electronics company.If Amazon does not pull this camera from their inventory I may begin to have similar sentiments toward them as well.I am not angry.  I'm genuinely shocked that Canon and Amazon could sell a product with known issues.Thanks

Reviews.Title: Very pixelated image
Reviews.Author: Jeff F
Reviews.Content: I selected this camera based on my previous Canon PowerShot A100IS that I had for years and loved it along with need for a camera that takes "AA" batteries.The photo quality of the camera was very poor and was even evident on the camera screen. When I transferred the image to the computer I had the same results. The image at full size was not crisp and when I magnified it just once, it showed very pixelated. I realize that this is the low end camera, but the image quality was around the same as my 1.3MP camera from 10 years ago. I had also just tried the Canon Power A810 with similar results and had returned that same day also. I finally purchased a Nikon CoolPix L26 that I am happy with except the boot time.I am glad Amazon has a good return policy.

Reviews.Title: Cheap camera- cheap quality
Reviews.Author: J. G. Daniels
Reviews.Content: I was encouraged by the good reviews of this camera and the fact that it used AA batteries instead of rechargeable and had an optical viewfinder.  Also, I have had two previous Canon cameras and have been very pleased.  This camera is very cheaply made, is slow to actually snap a picture and indoor picture quality is poor.  I bought it as a retirement gift for my Mother this summer and I will be replacing it at Christmas with a better camera.  I bought my wife a Panasonic FH25 last year and it is far and away a better camera for a bit more money.

Reviews.Title: Poorer photo resolution to Canon Powershot A1000IS
Reviews.Author: Amy Ong "Amy Ong"
Reviews.Content: Before buying this Canon Powershot A1300 which is a 16MP digital camera, I have owned and used Canon predecessor Powershot A1000IS 10MP digital camera for a few years.This camera is touted as 16MP. However, when taking the same photo (with and without optical zoom) using the A1000IS, surprisingly the A1300 photo has much poorer resolution, as compared to A1000IS. A1300 is also much lighter, which may be a good thing if quality is not being compromised. I am still retaining my old trusty Canon Powershot A1000IS as it seems the optics and optical zoom is of much better quality.Nevertheless, given the price, this camera is still worth buying as a first digital camera.

Reviews.Title: Canon Powershot A1300
Reviews.Author: Mick West
Reviews.Content: My first Powershot was an a 550.  Quality and capabilities have come a long way.  I'm amazed by the resolution. This is one of the few Flat cameras that still has a single eye view finder. That one item alone puts it in a class by itself.  The controls are a bit more tricky than previous models, and, they're easily mastered.  People are always surprised that a particular image was produced with an inexpensive Flat camera. Cameras don't take photographs, people take photographs.

Reviews.Title: Great Value and pics at any price
Reviews.Author: F. Wise "JV"
Reviews.Content: I own 2 high-end DSLR Canons, 60D and T2i, and this takes just as good of still pictures in good light at similar lens zoom levels, etc. Of course, those other high-end cameras give you lots of lens options, but for an affordable P&S;, this is hard to beat. I love that it works well with 2 AA batteries that you can get just about anywhere at any time (I use rechargeable AA's and carry a couple of regular AAs for backup). The HD video is decent though a little shaky which I attribute to the extreme lightweightness of the camera which allows for micro-movements (breathing) to move the camera around in little steps. But on a tripod, I imagine it would be fairly smooth.There are also a lot of adjustments you can make like the degree of "vividness" you want via the "LIVE" setting (it's actually a "warmth" setting). Of course, you need to know how to get into these advanced features and I imagine most people who buy this camera won't know how to access it and tweak the system. Anyway, if you know how to tweak things, this is a great affordable camera that can go anywhere and do most things well for hardly any $$. It's amazing how cameras keep advancing. If this camera had come out 5 years ago, you probably could have sold it for thousands with all it can do.

Reviews.Title: A Big Mistake
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I usually never write bad product reviews, but i have to this time. Over the past 25 years or so I have had many Cannon film camera. One of their 1st point and shoots took better photos than my pro camera. BUT the A1300 is not the same. From when I took it out of the box it was cheap and plastic. Fisher Price? We tried it over the next week at a few different events and it wouldn't focus. You can;t have a point and shoot that won't focus. You have to rely on it to do the work. And it took like 10-15 seconds to recharge the flash between shots. I sent it back in 2 weeks for an Amazon refund and bought a Panasonic that is great. Sorry Cannon, cutting manufacturing quality does now pay out for the consumer.

Reviews.Title: Great camera for the money
Reviews.Author: Gary Clark "mr vino"
Reviews.Content: Pros: Take very nice pictures. My wife had to have a viewfinder and this is one of the few cameras, if there are a few, that has one.Cons: I liked the older model, as most of the camera functions were set with a dial. This one is all screen menu driven.The Zoom is 5X optical, then switches to digital after the zoom is extended past the 5X mark, and the shots get grainy and blurry.

Reviews.Title: Great Compact Camera for the Price
Reviews.Author: J. S Thomas "Jethro"
Reviews.Content: I take roughly 14,000-15,000 photos a year for my job, yeah thats alot, and I wanted to upgrade from my very reliable Kodak thats showing its age.  I decided on the A1300 since it has a view finder, uses AA batteries and is easy to drop into the pocket and the wide angle lense.  I find the camera very well built, easy to use, the LCD screen is easy to see, the view finder is spot on.  I gave it 4 stars due to low light issues, not no light but low light.  The camera seems to have a difficult time focusing in lower light and I tend to get blurry shots if rushed.  However, if i take my time let the camera do its thing I tend to get better focused shots in low light.  I really have no complaints, i'll update the review on further use in low light conditions as it may be user error but will see.  Overall i would recommend this camera for everyday use, the zoom is great and easy to use, im not a video guy but played around with it and it seems to do well and picked up all the sounds in the room, its a great camera for the price.

Reviews.Title: A great camera. Good pictires. Good Macro
Reviews.Author: CyberCat
Reviews.Content: Clear pictures. Excellent macro to less than 0.5 inch. AA battery. Compared 100 pictures of the same subject taken with the A1300 to the same subject taken at the same time with my Nikon D5200 24 Meg Pixel camera. While the D5200 showed better resolution(24 mp Nikon  vs  16 mp for the Canon)  as expected, the A1300 is a great camera and cost only 1/14 the price of the Nikon, is lighter and very easy to use..

Reviews.Title: Huge delay
Reviews.Author: KimBeau
Reviews.Content: I was warned in other's reviews, but did not listen.  This camera has a huge delay.  I get nothing but pictures of people as they leave.  It can be used for nothing but still shots.  Then the camera goes on hold to charge the flash after every picture.  Wish I could send it back.

Reviews.Title: Great Little Camera
Reviews.Author: Dr. Terrence McGarty
Reviews.Content: I have used this for six months as a backup for trips where I cannot lug my Pentax. Initially I was concerned because of its size and low cost. However it is great and provides excellent pictures with fine resolution and good pixel count. I use it primarily for plant close ups on field trips and it is rugged and with the view finder it does exactly what I want with flower and leaf close ups. The battery life is superb and the camera has not gone through heat and humidity as well ans ice and snow. For the price the results are what I was looking for.

Reviews.Title: Despite it's Light Weight Feel - It's not a cheap camera
Reviews.Author: Lucas Persell "L.P."
Reviews.Content: Got this as a Christmas gift for my fiancee, as she had been talking about wanting a camera that wasn't part of her phone.I came across this one, got it, and have been totally satisfied since. My first concern was that it was so light that it was going to be 'cheap', but after using it for a while now, I can honestly say that it's not cheap at all. The picture quality is wonderful and its' ability to shoot 5 minute movies is another major plus.His camera is definitely something that I would recommend to anyone looking for a nice camera.

Reviews.Title: Highly satisfied.
Reviews.Author: Alan Booth
Reviews.Content: The camersa is just I expected it to be. I prefer to frame my pics using an optical viewfinder especialy in bright sunlight.

Reviews.Title: Great Deal - With a Viewfinder!
Reviews.Author: japack
Reviews.Content: This is a nicely designed camera that takes great photos.  It is well-priced and comes with a viewfinder, whcih I considered essential.

Reviews.Title: Great little camera
Reviews.Author: Robert Maurer
Reviews.Content: I have been using and abusing a less expensive Canon Power Shot for about 5 years, but I wanted a point and shoot that had a view finder.  I have gotten good service from the old Canon, so it was an easy decision to go with another Canon. I am very happy with the new one, not only because of the view finder, but also it is more compact than the older one, has a nicely designed hand hold, is more user friendly and takes great pictures.  Nothing fancy, but a great little camera for the money.

Reviews.Title: Point and shoot made easy
Reviews.Author: WLB
Reviews.Content: This is a great little point and shoot camera.  My wife wanted another simple small camera that took regular AA batterys, and had a view finder.  This is the only camera we could find that met her requirements.  It took great xmas pictures.

Reviews.Title: Considering its price, it's excellent
Reviews.Author: S. Vogt
Reviews.Content: I paid a whopping $80 for this camera at my local Micro Center. If you are on a strict budget and want something with a little more flexibility than your phone, the Canon A1300 is a great option. Especially for traveling because of the AA battery power source.The camera is made of plastic like most in this price range but still feels well put together. It has a nice grip on the front making it comfortable to hold and shoot with. You have a straight-forward control setup on the back. The ? button is a complete guide to all the camera's functions to help you out if you don't understand what a certain feature will do etc etc.The LCD on back is not the highest resolution but pretty good for this class of camera and mostly visible in most shooting conditions. Of course you can always adjust the LCD brightness in the menu system to suit your needs. The viewfinder is not very big but as far as I know, it's the only camera in this price range that offers one. And point and shoots that cost twice and three times as much don't have one, so it was nice for Canon to include it on this model.I was actually pleasantly surprised at the shooting performance on this model. The AF is reasonably quick in good light, it slows down some in dim light but it's still not too bad. Shot to shot times are somewhat slow. One slightly annoying thing (and this has been true on previous A series models as well) is that if you're wanting to shoot using the flash..you have to wait for it to charge. The delay is relatively brief but can get annoying after awhile. But in this class of camera, that is something I'm willing to forgive. The lens sounds kind of loud and mechanical when zooming in and out, but not as bad as some of the older A-series models.As with most cameras in this price class, you don't have full manual control. You can control the ISO and other things like exposure compensation. However, one thing the camera does have is a function called Live View Control. Basically this allows you to adjust the darkness and brightness, color vibrancy, and to make the scene warmer or cooler. This is a great feature to have in lieu of manual control and its highly recommended that you exploit this feature in order to get the best photos out of your A1300.Overall image quality is very nice. With good color reproduction, sharpness, and detail capture. Honestly, I read some of the reviews of this camera saying it has poor image quality and wondered if they were talking about the same camera or are expecting too much out of an entry-level point and shoot. But the camera can produce some very nice photos especially if you use the Live View Control and other adjustments. Its low-light photos aren't too bad. There is increased noise and detail smearing, especially above ISO400 but not as bad as some others I have seen. You can still get usable low-light photos out of this camera if you are just uploading them to facebook or flickr and not blowing them up to huge sizes.Video is not bad on the camera but suitable for short clips. I would not buy this camera primarily for shooting video, though. Some of the more expensive powershots are better suited for video capture.Overall, this is a very nice camera and a great value. It produces decent photos, has an AA battery source which makes it a great camera to travel with, its comfortable to shoot with, and the shooting performance is decent for its class. Highly recommended!

Reviews.Title: Great value for the price
Reviews.Author: M. Irish
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera at Amazon.com to replace my old Kodak Easy Share.  This Canon camera is very user friendly, and I am impressed with the quality of both pictures and videos. I am thoroughly happy with the purchase, and would definitely recommend it to anyone looking for a good all-around camera at a very reasonable price.

Reviews.Title: Great point and shot
Reviews.Author: Shirl
Reviews.Content: I have been looking for a compact point and shot with a view finder for a good long time.  This camera does everything that I wanted.  It is very light weight, even with the case (purchased seperately) it fits nicely in my jacket pocket or purse.  The picture quality is what you would expect from Canon.  Very pleased and would recommend.

Reviews.Title: Canon Powershot A1300IS
Reviews.Author: Walt Z.
Reviews.Content: Very user-friendly. It's a real plus to have an optical viewfinder as well as the LCD monitor, especially useful in bright sunlight.  Having the monitor swivel would be a welcome feature.  The only downside is that you have to open the battery compartment to remove the media card.

Reviews.Title: Handy little camera
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: Bought this camera for my granddaughter who starts college this year, she is having a blast with the different settings this camera has. She likes the vivid settings, it really brings out the Arizona sunsets, and for Fourth of July she used the firework settings, and it actually worked well, pretty amazing for a basic point and shoot camera. I would recommend this camera to anyone that wants a point and shoot camera for all the little moments you want to remember.

Reviews.Title: Like Viewfinder & does a good job
Reviews.Author: M. Smith "Mike"
Reviews.Content: 'Pocket' cameras of course have their limitations, but for a small 'pocket' camera at this price I am pleased with this product.  I shoot with 2 cameras, a 'big boy' SLR and this 'pocket' camera and they both have their place - the SLR for quality and versatility and the 'pocket' camera for convenience and availability when I don't want to carry the larger SLR.  I rated 4-stars because of this camera's inherent limitations, but it's a fine camera especially for the price.  This little 'pocket' camera does a decent job and I certainly appreciate and use the optical viewfinder.  I would purchase this camera again.

Reviews.Title: Good little camera
Reviews.Author: Helen
Reviews.Content: I just took a tour of Europe and did not want to carry a big bulky camera around, so I used this one on the trip.  Sometimes I would have liked a little more zoom power but otherwise it is light, easy to use, easy to delete pictures you don't want.  Sometimes it was a bit slow between pictures especially if you wanted to change zoom settings.  But for simple, easy use, it is just fine.  I would recommend this camera.

Reviews.Title: You get what you pay for!
Reviews.Author: A. Clausen
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for my mom. She's not great with electronics so I wanted something simple to use and without all those ridiculous features that nobody uses. I grew up in a PowerShot family so I trusted this device based on it's name.When I asked my mom how she liked it, she said that it had a very annoying delay between when you press the shutter release button and when the picture is actually snapped. I thought she just had it in a weird mode or didn't know what she was really doing (she's a 60+ year old lady, c'mon) but when I started playing around with it, she was actually 100% right! Indeed there is a pretty annoying delay. In fact, if you want to use the flash, I hope you have lots of time to let the flash 'charge'. I know that cameras have to charge a capacitor to fire the flash, but this delay is about 3-4 seconds. It doesn't sound like a long time but it is quite irritating.The pictures are also pretty poor. Inside, (even when it's not super dark) the pictures come out very blurred. I can't tell if it's a focusing problem or just a slow shutter speed but the pictures come out very bad. Amazon claims that it has image stabilization, but I highly doubt it. It doesn't say anywhere on the camera about it having IS. And based on the blurred pics, I am skeptical.I haven't played with all the shooting options. In fact, I've only played with the camera for a total of maybe 15 minutes, but for that short amount of time I could tell that this is a very low quality camera. I have a good amount of PowerShot experience and this thing is a pretty sad variation of the PowerShot family. You get what you pay for.I would be sending this back if my silly mom didn't throw away the packaging. Spend the extra money and get something better. I am honestly very surprised this has so many positive reviews.

Reviews.Title: not great for Canon
Reviews.Author: Derek Vincent
Reviews.Content: I have owned several Canon point and shoot and professional cameras and have been very happy with them for the most part. I ordered this camera because I liked the idea of having a viewfinder. The cameras menus, etc were easy to navigate but I found the focus was unreliable, especially in the macro mode. I had a lot of trouble with out of focus images and promptly returned it.

Reviews.Title: Compact, simple, but low light performance is atrocious
Reviews.Author: That Guy from Seattle
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera because I wanted a small point-and-shoot that I could throw into my pocket and whip out for a quick shot here and there.Pros: Low price, very compact and lightweight, simple and intuitive controls, takes AA batteries, can record video.Cons: Image quality is pretty bad in general and low light shots tend to be noisy to the point of absurdity, the auto focus system can be fickle at times.It's small, intuitive to use, and has a good price, but... I'll likely be returning this camera and looking at another a few steps up or maybe something from another manufacturer. Image quality is poor with soft details and lots of noise in well lit shots with low light shots being nearly garbage due to the absurd levels of noise. I own two Nikon DSLRs so this is probably my karmic punishment for going "outside the family". I didn't expect this thing to stand toe-to-toe with a D7000 but I at least hoped it would best an HTC Incredible 2 cellphone for image quality. It doesn't.

Reviews.Title: Just get it!
Reviews.Author: Amazon Shopper
Reviews.Content: Overall, this is the best under $200 camera you will find. This camera will meet all of your needs.  Don't waste your money on some cheap camera, this thing will do you proud. So many features, I don't even want to talk about. Just get it!

Reviews.Title: The quality of the indoors photos is unacceptable
Reviews.Author: Jul Nis
Reviews.Content: The quality of the indoors photos is unacceptable, even for an inexpensive camera, so I'm very disappointed in Canon. On the highest quality settings the indoors photos are very grainy and blurry - similar to my iPhone photos in quality. I was looking for something simple for my father, who didn't want too many bells and whistles, but this one is going back...

Reviews.Title: terrible
Reviews.Author: Kendy P.
Reviews.Content: I'm not happy with this camera, it takes too long between shots to charge the battery and half the pictures have been blurry,

Reviews.Title: too bad?
Reviews.Author: itsMalcolm
Reviews.Content: Too bad I gave this camera away, to a relative.  I "upgraded" to a Canon A1400 & a Canon A810, which are each nice cameras, BUT--the pictures I get from those just aren't as "bright" & "crisp" and "vivid" as those I got from the good ol' Canon Powershot A1300.  I miss it.  Might buy another A1300, fits in a pocket, takes great photos.  A1300, I miss you....

Reviews.Title: Love the camera but it stops working!
Reviews.Author: Lisa Renee Sims
Reviews.Content: This is the second A1300 that I bought, and both of these cameras had a lens disfunction.  The lens gets "stuck" in the on position and then it won't retract.  But other than that it is the best camera that I've used - it has a view-finder, the movie function works great, it is easy to understand - I just wish it would keep working!

Reviews.Title: Great little camera
Reviews.Author: charlie
Reviews.Content: I like the window viewer on the back.  Many times the sun prevents a clear picture on the screen.  Nice clear, clean pictures.  Not too many gadgets to figure out.  Point and shoot!

Reviews.Title: Awesome
Reviews.Author: gregory mitchell noble
Reviews.Content: This is a great pocket camera.  I took it to a couple of concerts and got some really great pictures and its easy to use.  great price for a great camera

Reviews.Title: What a great little camera!
Reviews.Author: Teresa Jordan "Tesa Jordan"
Reviews.Content: I am knocked out by the quality of such a small camera. Lots of settings, does video, shoots fireworks.. a great bargain. The total selling feature for me was that this camera still has an (old school) viewfinder! Batteries last and last.. I use rechargeables, but my old HP still ate them up quickly. I love Canon's technology and also have a canon camcorder. You can't go wrong with this one!

Reviews.Title: Not really a good camera.
Reviews.Author: Kingy47
Reviews.Content: It seemed like a toy almost and sometimes did whatever it wanted to in terms of flashing or turning off and such. Mine could have been defective but overall I just didn't like it for the price.

Reviews.Title: Optical Viewfinder and LCD a decision maker
Reviews.Author: shutterbug33
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera, not because I think it is the very best camera and not because it has the zoom ratio I may prefer but because it is the only compact camera I could find that offered the optical viewfinder.  I have my DSLR and the best super zoom (my opinion) made but I am going on a trip and want to be able to "pack light" on the trail.  Even though the A1300 only has 5x zoom, with the 16MP, I can shoot a sharp image, crop half of it any way I choose, and still have an acceptable result, which would then be like having a 10x zoom @ 8MP.  Thank you Canon for marketing not only to the newer generations of LCD users but also to those of us who want to use an optical viewfinder for stabilization and preference.  These days, to get an optical viewfinder you have to get into the $350+ range.  Kudos!

Reviews.Title: Trip to the beach, gators in the lagoon
Reviews.Author: Warren Bistline
Reviews.Content: Only drawback is time to recharge flash, but considering it operates on 2 AA batteries (easy to find), it is good for my purposes.  Color and sharpness of images are very good.

Reviews.Title: Cool and small
Reviews.Author: D. Oblak "Tahoe"
Reviews.Content: Great photos from France. Easy and small enough to take anywhere. Lot's of auto-features that make a variety of shots and shooting situations easy and memorable. Love this camera. Bought one for my wife and she said I should get one so I didn't use hers on our vacation. She was right. I have used a couple larger Canon SLR Digitals and have a Rebel XTi, which are greatcameras. But, s little P+S w/ 16 Megs and an optical view finder-with zoom are perfect. Cameras without real viewfinders are losers in high-sunlight, snow, dark scenes and difficult shooting situations. Buy one of these before they go away. No Kidding!

Reviews.Title: granddaughter going to france
Reviews.Author: Patricia Morr
Reviews.Content: Bought it for her birthday for her trip to France in a few days...she just loves it and anxious to use it in France

Reviews.Title: Small but mighty
Reviews.Author: P. Wolf
Reviews.Content: I purchased a Nikon Coolpix L28 for $100, but after a couple test shots that were not as crisp, so I returned it.  I didn't think any camera mfg made view finders. So the fact the powershot had a viewfinder, and it was a Canon and also $100 I ordered it.  I have had it for all of one hour, but so far I love it.  Handles nicely...nice test shots, and I can take pictures by the pool with the view finder, instead of guessing and aiming with the LCD. Let's hope Canon keeps their consumer savey and never give up on the viewfinder, or their quality.

Reviews.Title: Excellent camera
Reviews.Author: Roadside
Reviews.Content: Would definately buy it again.  It's much better than the old Kodak I replaced it with.  It has more features than I'll ever use.

Reviews.Title: This is the only inexpensive small camera with a view finder.  Instructions very easy to understand. Very happy.
Reviews.Author: J. Gorger
Reviews.Content: This is the only inexpensive small camera with a view finder.  Instructions very easy to understand. Very happy with it.

Reviews.Title: Decent camera for the price
Reviews.Author: william a. mcmanus
Reviews.Content: I have always been a hard core Canon fan.  But lately I have not been overly impressed with the product.  Now it could be that I am a terrible photographer but I will probably go with a different product line in the future.  The pictures didn't seem to be real clear and the shots I took were dark and lacked depth.

Reviews.Title: Great camera for remote places
Reviews.Author: naturegal
Reviews.Content: So happy to still be able to find an AA battery operated digital camera for my rainforest and jungle adventures.  No need to worry about finding a "recharging" outlet.  The viewfinder is also appreciated when in more sunny places.  Easy to follow  onscreen guide.  Canon, please keep this one going for all of us off-the-beaten-path picture takers.

Reviews.Title: Great camera!
Reviews.Author: AndriaD
Reviews.Content: My old 8 megapixel Nikon had given up the ghost, so I needed to replace it with something affordable, but hopefully better -- my hopes were answered with this Canon A1300!  First off, the battery life is terrific, which was the main point I was looking at when I read previous reviews of this camera and several others.  The pictures are very sharp and clear, and the zoom function works beautifully, and was MUCH easier to figure out than that on my old Nikon.  There are only two drawbacks to this camera that I have found, so far; when you click the shutter to take the pic, it seems to take a while before you can use the camera again -- which makes it iffy to line up horizontally when taking a series for a panorama.  I suspect this is probably common to all low-priced cameras (same thing with my old Nikon).  The other thing may be something I can overcome, as I grow more familiar with the camera: when taking pics outdoors, the colors seem to have very low saturation, very washed-out looking; I always have to boost saturation in Photoshop, before putting the pics on my website, but since I have to scale down the immense size anyway, not really a big deal, and perhaps I can figure out something about the "compensation" setting that will alleviate this problem -- I'm a point-and-shoot photographer, not a photography-geek.  But, despite the colors seeming weak, the hue of the images is right on the money, no weird color-artifacts as I have sometimes seen with other cameras, and no yellowing when taking pics indoors -- a HUGE problem with the old Nikon.  As others have reported, the accompanying software gives all kinds of error msgs when you try to install it, and even when you try to update it, though afterward, it seems to be installed and functional.  However I had to uninstall it, and the "Canon Picture Window" or whatever it is, because when you plug in the camera to the computer, turn it on, and the "picture window" splash screen comes up, it takes *****FOREVER***** almost like the whole system is "hung," and it hangs right in front of everything else, so you can't even go about your business while it's ***SLOWLY*** starting the software.  Nuts to that; I uninstalled all software that came with the camera, and use the TWAIN-WIA interface in Photoshop to get the pics from the camera, and doing that, it's a heck of a lot quicker to download the images than from my old Nikon.  So, they make excellent cameras, and truly crappy software.  Oh, and the old-style optical viewfinder is a real gem; I used it just today when photographing my garden in bright sunlight, and the LCD was nearly invisible in the bright light; really excellent addition to the standard inexpensive digital camera!  Another really cool feature I discovered, though I can't personally use it with the printer I currently have, is the ability to connect it directly to a printer via USB, for printing direct from the camera.  Perhaps I'll have a photo-printer at some point, and this feature will be REALLY handy.  So, although the camera is still a bit new to me, and I still have a few things to figure out about it, on the whole I am TERRIFICALLY pleased with it.

Reviews.Title: Best compact camera for the price
Reviews.Author: Green Eyes
Reviews.Content: In addition to the usual Canon quality and value, this camera has a feature nearly unique on current point-and-shoot cameras: A REAL OPTICAL VIEWFINDER !!! This is a fantastic 'old school' feature that nearly all point-and-shoots once had, but is nearly impossible to find now on a budget-priced camera.You can compose photos much better with a real viewfinder than is possible with a 2-3 inch display. Using the viewfinder you can steady the camera against your face, compose your shot even in bright sunlight, and extend battery life by turning off the display while shooting. You also don't look like a drunken goober holding your camera out at arm's length and squinting your eyes while taking pictures.Can you imagine buying an SLR or top-of-the-line compact without a viewfinder?!? It would be like buying a car without a steering wheel. All decent digital cameras should retain this feature. Canon is to be commended for bringing it back in a pocket-sized camera that only cost a hundred bucks.

Reviews.Title: Feature/Price comparison
Reviews.Author: R. B. Duncan
Reviews.Content: I got this on Amazon for $70, so I certainly can't complain about it being worth the price.  My most recent check of this item shows a price of $149, so I got a good deal.  I would recommend for $70.

Reviews.Title: Poor Quality Pictures
Reviews.Author: Aslihan
Reviews.Content: Very Poor quality pictures especially indoors. It is fine if you are taking pictures outdoors it is OK but in indoors the quality of pictures are simply very poor and blurry.

Reviews.Title: yearbook camera
Reviews.Author: M. E. Thornsbury
Reviews.Content: I purchased two of these cameras for my school yearbook students use.  So very disappointed in them.  Every Canon I have owned has been great.  These cameras take grainy pictures.  Every time we try to use pictures taken by these cameras, we end up not being able to use them in the yearbook. This applies especially to anything we have tried to zoom in on.  Really disappointed!

Reviews.Title: OK so far
Reviews.Author: Woogies
Reviews.Content: Have only been using it for a month.  Sometimes it locks up and the error message says 'card error."  If I switch from the new card to an old one, it's OK.  Some photos still blurry.  Acceptable performance for the price.

Reviews.Title: A good step up.
Reviews.Author: Tigergirl0318
Reviews.Content: I was looking for a new camera. I really wanted a point and shoot, not quite ready to jump into the  DSLR pool yet, but I wanted a step up from my Kodak Easyshare.. This is a good camera for that middle ground. I like that it has a viewfinder. Makes it much easier to take pictures on a sunny day. I also really like that it takes AA batteries. This is a must for me. I am terrible at charging things. I do not worry about being out and my battery dieing. I can always pick up AA batteries. All in all I really like this camera.

Reviews.Author: Warren R. Simmons
Reviews.Content: Bought for my wife.  She loves it. Has shot hundreds of pictures already for her work. Wish I could afford fancier camera.

Reviews.Title: Good Camera, Good Value
Reviews.Author: T Schrock
Reviews.Content: Our Canon A510 bit the dust, this seemed to be a good fit for a replacement and on sale at Amazon.  Didn't even have to go through the manual to access most of the features, as the menus and controls still had enough similarity to the old camera.  Nice large screen.

Reviews.Title: Easy basic camera
Reviews.Author: Kathleen Larsen
Reviews.Content: Simple to use but packed with features - this camera is perfect for all types of photos. The flash is very sensitive and does not over-brighten the subjects. Close-ups are great too. The short and sweet instruction booklet gets you going right away, and the help button right on the camera explains the function and how to use it. It is small but doesn't feel like a toy. Fits pocket or purse easily.

Reviews.Title: Good camera
Reviews.Author: Gloria
Reviews.Content: Ordered this camera because my beloved canon elf was eating batteries. I like the idea it takes 2 aa  less expensive and easy to obtain anywhere u r .It is lightweight and fits well in your hand

Reviews.Title: A classic point and shoot camera.
Reviews.Author: Mountie Ellis Morris
Reviews.Content: I am far sighted and therefore find cameras that have only an LED display absolutely useless. This camera was the only one with the features I wanted that has a real genuine view finder. Now I can see what I'm recording even in strong light, out door conditions. The case seems a little light for the extreme back country out door conditions where I find my self taking pictures so it remains to be seen how that will hold up, but for most normal users this would be an excellent camera.

Reviews.Title: Camera with viewfinder
Reviews.Author: paco
Reviews.Content: This camera does everything I needed, The viewfinder makes it possible to get great pictures in the snow, when it is difficult to see the subjects thru the LCD.

Reviews.Title: Very nice camera
Reviews.Author: Wolfer99 "wolfer99"
Reviews.Content: I love the camera with the optical view finder as it is very hard to use a camera with only the LCD view finder in the sunlight

Reviews.Title: Great for outside, not inside, photos
Reviews.Author: C. S. Dietrich "granpa expert"
Reviews.Content: This is a fairly priced point and shoot camera.  It takes decent pictures.  Outside in normal to bright light the camera's response is fast and the pictures are clear and crisp.  Inside with low light the flash goes off but the pictures are grainy and it takes several long seconds to be ready for the next shot.  The delay is frustrating and aggravating.  I have missed several good pictures.  Our grandkids are cute for only so long and missing inside shots is bothersome.I would not recommend this camera for anyone who wants to take inside flash pictures one after the other.  It just won't go off.Otherwise, the camera is solid, typical of Canon quality.  I bought it for the viewer, so we could see what a picture was going to be without looking at the screen, which is sometimes tough in bright sunlight.  For this it is great.  It is easy to use and is great for all outdoor photography, even very close shots of flowers and insects.

Reviews.Title: Canon PowerShot
Reviews.Author: LeoJ
Reviews.Content: Very good camera for the money. We bought it for 2 reasons, view finder (Hard to take a picture in the sun without one), batteries are double A (Easy to find and replace when out and about).

Reviews.Title: Canon PowerShot Camera
Reviews.Author: C.
Reviews.Content: I like this camera.  It is one of the only ones with a view finder.  It doesn't have some of the features I would like, but on a whole it is a good camera and takes good pictures.

Reviews.Title: Canon powershot A 1300 digital camera
Reviews.Author: Yousry Matta "yusrimatta"
Reviews.Content: I got this new camera almost 3 months ago, the price was reasonable with fast shipping as usual from my favorite website the amazon, the camera worked well with sharp pictures both indoors and outdoors but the only disadvantage is excessive battery consumption, it slowed in action when batteries were weak so better to have fresh ones in your bag

Reviews.Title: Settings
Reviews.Author: Cynthia Martz "Phoenix"
Reviews.Content: The settings annoy me. I have decided to stop changing them. The Macro setting takes excellent photographs. I am trying too learn the perks and perils of this powershot.

Reviews.Title: Bought for my wife
Reviews.Author: Ira H. Bernstein
Reviews.Content: This does exactly what it is supposed to.  It is an inexpensive, easy to use camera which my wife has enjoyed.

Reviews.Title: Good little camera
Reviews.Author: nancy
Reviews.Content: Gave as a gift to a semi proffesional to carry around for everyday use.  She loves it - easy to use and takes great picts.

Reviews.Title: GREAT CAMERA
Reviews.Author: Bruce Fichter
Reviews.Content: Everything I  need in a camera !!!small in size ...big in options....AA batteries are the way to go

Reviews.Title: Best for an amateur like me.
Reviews.Author: Dmitry-Floridian "Floridian"
Reviews.Content: Probably is too weak for any artistic/professional purposes, but perfect for regular family events' recordings - steady and movies. Easy to read manual and operations themselves - best value for the money!

Reviews.Title: Itis exactly what I was looking for
Reviews.Author: Richard Mullins
Reviews.Content: I bought this for my wife for Christmas to replace a camera that did not have a viewfinder.  It is one of the few remaining reasonably priced cameras with an optical viewfinder.  Without it you never know what you are taking a picture of when you are outside in bright sunlight, and I live in Florida.  Contrary to one review I read the optical viewfinder does zoom in and out so you can see exactly what you are photographing.  Also I replaced the two AA batteries with rechargeable ones (with their own charger) and carry two non-rechargeable AA batteries in case the rechargeable batteries lose their charge at the wrong moment.Pictures are just fine although other reviewers have noted that sharpness is not great for indoor flash pictures.  And loading time between pictures is slow.  Overall my wife is very pleased with this camera.  Well worth the price.

Reviews.Title: NICE EVERY DAY USE CAMERA (RECOMENDED)
Reviews.Author: HAPPY
Reviews.Content: NICE CAMERY AND COMPACT GREAT PICTURES MY WIFE HAD ALWAYS USED A 35 MM CAMERA. THIS HER FIRST DIGITAL. SHE LIKES THE EASE OF USE.OVER ALL GOOD PICTURES LIGHT WEIGHT AND EASY TO USE

Reviews.Title: Great simple camera
Reviews.Author: Sergio Venegas
Reviews.Content: I'm not into all the bells and whistles and like to keep things low tech. This camera does what I want it to do and that's take great pictures. Its easy to use and you can figure out how to operate it without using the manual.  I love Canon cameras and have owned many throughout the years. I'd recommend this camera to anyone just wanting to take pictures without all the rest of the techno stuff that other cameras offer.

Reviews.Title: Service was AWESOME!
Reviews.Author: tara
Reviews.Content: It was very clear before I ordered the camera that it wouldn't be shipped for 1-2 months. Less than a week after I ordered it, I was sent an email saying they're able to deliver it earlier. Then another email saying even earlier than that.! -awesome.
